etymologies: late Middle English: from Latin, from Greek Argos, the name of a watchman in Greek mythology who had a hundred eyes. After he was killed by Hermes, Hera used his eyes to decorate the peacock's tail

definitions: a long-tailed pheasant with generally brown plumage, found in Southeast Asia and Indonesia.

notes.text: Two species in the family Phasianidae: the male great argus (Argusianus argus) has lengthened secondary wing feathers bearing eyespots, spread during display; the crested argus (Rheinartia ocellata) has the longest tail feathers of any bird

shortDefinitions: long-tailed pheasant with generally brown plumage

definitions: a small brown or bluish Eurasian butterfly that typically has eye-like markings near the wing margins.

notes.text: Aricia and other genera, family Lycaenidae

shortDefinitions: small brown or bluish Eurasian butterfly with eyelike markings near wing margins

definitions: a silvery deep-bodied fish with round spots, widely distributed throughout the tropical Indo-Pacific region in both fresh and salt water.
shortDefinitions: silvery deep-bodied fish with round spots
